Hey Ken,

    If you decide to use a FPS engine instead of an RTS engine you may wish
to contact ID Software.  From our experience, they can be pretty open about
sharing.
    For our virtual reality emergency department (www.imedi.org/edx.htm),
after a short pitch about our project, ID said they were open to the idea of
giving us their latest graphical engine (which at the time was Quake 3 and
cost $300,000) to build our system for free.  Ultimately, Alan Fischer, our
chief technical lead, decided to build his own system which is what you see
on the page.
    Keep in mind also that previous iterations of ID software cost less
(though still expensive.)  If I recall, it was $100,000 for Quake 2, and
$10,000 for Quake 1.  But, at least at the time, if you go three generations
back, they release the code for free.  Given that Doom 3 is coming out soon,
Quake or Quake 2 code might soon be available for free.

    While I am posting to the group, I might also mention that anyone who
would like to apply neuroevolution to evolving effective robotic navigation
in hospitals or using them to predict which patients might be about to die
or who shouldn't be sent home, we would love to hear project proposals at
the Medical Media Lab.  We fund grants and research externships (food,
lodging, salary) in Washington D.C.

Thanks.

-Mike
---------------------------------
Michael Gillam, MD
Informatics Director, Evanston Northwestern Healthcare
Division of Emergency Medicine

Director, Institute for Medical Informatics Media Lab (www.imedi.org)
Director of Research, National Center for Emergency Medicine Informatics
(www.ncemi.org)
Washington D.C.

Chair, Web Educator's Interest Group
Society for Academic Emergency Medicine

> having to either rewrite an FPS engine ourselves, or go to a company
> and try to get them to let us use their proprietary code.
